chapter: Tuberculosis Of Bone And Joints-Tb Of Bone

questions.question: A 28-year-old intravenous drug abuser presents with a history of pain, fever, cough with blood in sputum, night sweats, weight loss, and swelling in his right hip joint. A cold abscess is suspected near the joint upon further examination and investigations. Which of the following is characteristic of this condition?

options.A: Rapid destruction of cartilage by proteolytic enzymes
options.B: Rarely involves the ends of long bones
options.C: Always causes more significant systemic symptoms

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Spreads through the hematogenous route Explanation: The patient in this scenario is most probably having Tuberculous arthritis with the primary focus being pulmonary TB. Tuberculous arthritis typically occurs due to the hematogenous spread of Mycobacterium tuberculosis bacteria from a primary focus, most commonly the lungs. Etiology of Tuberculosis of bone and joints: Most common causative organism: Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Sometimes the causative organism is bovine , it spreads through raw milk and is less common in India. Predisposing conditions: Chronic debilitating disorders, diabetes, drug abuse, prolonged corticosteroid medication, AIDS, and conditions with reduced defense mechanisms. Pathogenesis: Bone and joint tuberculosis are always secondary to the primary focus in the lungs, lymph nodes, and other sites. Mode of spread from the primary focus: Haematogenous or direct extension from a neighboring focus. The sequence in which bone and joint tuberculosis affects different areas: Spine > hip > knee > elbow. Most commonly involves the ends of the long bone. Epiphyseal cartilage is not a barrier to invasion. Therefore, the infection reaches the joint sooner. (Option B) Infection persists as chronic osteomyelitis only in the vertebral bodies, and the greater trochanter of the femur. The natural course of the disease: Inflammation stage: It causes local bone necrosis, caseation, and demineralization due to hyperemia. Without resistance or treatment, bone cortices erode, leading to sub-periosteal abscesses. Cold abscesses may form and burst, creating sinuses. Pathological fractures can occur in affected bones. Joints: Develop low-grade synovitis, with thickened synovial membranes. Unlike pyogenic arthritis where proteolytic enzymes cause severe early destruction of the articular cartilage, tubercular infection causes slow destruction. Once the synovium is inflamed, it starts destroying the cartilage from the periphery. (Option A) This inflammatory synovium at the periphery of the cartilage is called Pannus. The joint fills with pus, causing lax ligaments and subluxation. Pus and debris may cause cold abscesses and chronic sinuses. Types of tubercular infection pathology: Proliferative response (common): Characterized by chronic granulomatous inflammation with a lot of fibrosis. Exudative response: Extensive caseation necrosis without much cellular reaction. This results in extensive pus formation. Healing stage: Heals by fibrosis, often leading to fibrous ankylosis, with bony ankylosis
questions.chapter_heading: Tuberculosis Of Bone And Joints-Tb Of Bone

questions.question: A 14-year-old girl presents to the orthopedic OPD with a four-month history of left knee pain, which worsens with activity and at night. She has had episodes of low-grade fever and fatigue but denies any recent trauma. Upon physical examination, the left knee has limited range of motion and noticeable soft-tissue swelling. An image of the X-ray of the left knee joint is shown below. What is Phemister’s triad, and how does it relate to this case?

options.A: A triad of symptoms indicating septic arthritis
options.B: A triad of radiological findings indicating tuberculous arthritis
options.C: A set of criteria for diagnosing osteosarcoma
options.D: A triad of radiological criteria for diagnosing Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) A triad of radiological findings indicating tuberculous arthritis Explanation: Phemister’s triad of juxta-articular osteopenia/osteoporosis, peripheral osseous erosions, and joint space narrowing suggests tuberculous arthritis but is nonspecific. X-ray findings: Characteristic signs are soft-tissue swelling and periarticular osteoporosis. Bone ends appear ‘washed-out, ’ and the articular space narrows. In children, epiphyses
questions.chapter_heading: Tuberculosis Of Bone And Joints-Tb Of Bone

questions.question: A 32-year-old woman with right hip drug-susceptible TB has been treated with first-line anti-tubercular drugs (HRZE) for two months. She no longer has fever, and night sweats. What is the next step in the management of this patient?

options.A: Discontinue therapy if symptoms have improved
options.C: Continue Isoniazid and Rifampicin for four months

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Continue Isoniazid and Rifampicin for four months Explanation: The standard treatment regimen for drug-susceptible skeletal TB involves an intensive phase of four drugs (Isoniazid, Rifampicin, Pyrazinamide, and Ethambutol) for two months, followed by a continuation phase of Isoniazid and Rifampicin for at least four more months (totaling six months of therapy). Since the patient is showing improvement, the next step is to transition to the continuation phase with Isoniazid and Rifampicin for the remaining four months. Medical treatment of Skeletal T.B: 1st line therapy (HRZES) Drug name Mechanism of action Dosage Complications/Side effects Isoniazid (INH) (H) Bacteriostatic It inhibits cell wall synthesis. 5 mg/kg/day Hepatotoxicity Peripheral neuritis Rifampicin (R) Bactericidal 10 mg/kg/day Hepatotoxicity Red coloured urine Pyrazinamide (Z) Bactericidal 25 mg/kg/day Hepatotoxicity Ethambutol (E) Bacteriostatic 15 mg/kg/day Optic neuritis Colour blindness Streptomycin (S) Bactericidal 15 mg/kg/day Vestibular damage Nephrotoxicity Circumoral paraesthesia 2nd line therapy Drug name Mechanism of action Dosage Complications/Side effects Para amino salicylic acid (PAS) Bacteriostatic 10 gm/day Anorexia, Nausea, Vomiting Ethionamide Bacteriostatic 15 mg/kg/day Anorexia, Nausea, Vomiting Cycloserine Bacteriostatic 1 gm/day CNS toxicity- Headache, Tremor, Dysarthria. Regimen: Musculoskeletal TB falls under category I of the WHO treatment category Category I treatment: 2 months of HRZE followed by 4 months of HR (Option A) Transition to second-line drugs (Option B): Second-line drugs are reserved for cases of drug-resistant TB or when patients are intolerant to first-line therapy. There is no indication of drug resistance or adverse effects in this patient. Therefore, switching to second-line drugs is unnecessary and would increase the risk of side effects. This option is also incorrect. Start surgical intervention (Option D): Surgery is not the first line of management for skeletal TB unless there is severe joint destruction, neurological complications, or failure to respond to medical therapy. In this case, the patient is responding well to medication, so surgical intervention is not indicated at this stage. This option is incorrect. Reference: Apley and Solomon’s System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, Edition 10th- Page 56. Spinal tuberculosis: A review - PMC (nih.gov) Treatment of tuberculosis patients - Implementing the WHO Stop TB Strategy - NCBI Bookshelf (nih.gov)
questions.chapter_heading: Tuberculosis Of Bone And Joints-Tb Of Bone

questions.question: A 40-year-old man presents with a three-month history of progressively worsening lower back pain, night sweats, and weight loss. There is no history of trauma. On spinal examination, there is significant tenderness over the thoracolumbar spine, gibbus with limited range of motion. Imaging reveals vertebral destruction and a paravertebral cold abscess. Blood tests show an elevated ESR and CRP. Which of the following factors makes the vertebral body particularly susceptible to the spread of tuberculosis bacteria?

options.A: Via the lymphatic vessels surrounding the spine
options.B: Through the Batson's paravertebral venous plexus
options.C: By direct extension from the intervertebral discs

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Through the Batson's paravertebral venous plexus Explanation: The vertebral body is more susceptible due to the blood supply of the spine. Embryologically: The lower half of the upper vertebrae, intervertebral disc, and upper half of the lower vertebrae have a common origin from a sclerotome which has its own blood supply, making this area susceptible to tuberculosis bacteria infection via a hematogenous route through Batson's venous plexus. Spinal Tuberculosis: Also known as Pott's Spine. The most common site of skeletal TB is the Spine. In the spine, the thoracolumbar region is mostly affected. Pathology: TB of the spine is always secondary. The bacteria reach the spine via the hematogenous route from the primary focus. (Option A) It spreads via the para-vertebral plexus of veins i.e., Batson's plexus, which has free communication with the visceral plexus of the abdomen. Batson's paravertebral venous plexus (Internal vertebral venous plexus) is a valveless plexus that spreads infection to the vertebral body. Rich vascular plexus in the subchondral region of each vertebrae makes it easier for TB bacteria to spread to the paradisiacal area. Granulomatous inflammation erodes the vertebral margins. This leads to disc degeneration and eventual destruction. Weakening of vertebral trabeculae causes vertebral collapse. Healing: Lytic areas in the bone are replaced by new bone. The adjacent vertebrae undergo fusion by bony bridges, which are permanent. Clinical manifestations: The usual clinical symptom is a painful stiff back, and radicular pain if the nerve root is compressed. By direct extension from the intervertebral discs (Option C): Intervertebral discs can be affected by TB, but the infection typically spreads to the vertebral body first via blood vessels, not directly from the discs. Through direct pulmonary tuberculosis (Option D): Tuberculosis often originates in the lungs and can spread to the spine, but this option is less specific regarding the route of spread to the vertebral body. The hematogenous spread via Batson's plexus is a more direct explanation for how the infection seeds in the vertebral body. This option is incorrect. Systemic symptoms like loss of appetite, and fever may or may not be present. Cold abscess: Pus and tubercular debris from a diseased vertebra. Called "cold" due to lack of typical inflammation signs (heat, redness). Pus can spread in any direction from the affected vertebra. Classical night cries. Early deformity to occur is loss of normal cervical and lumbar lordosis (due to paraspinal muscle spasm). GIBBUS is commonly seen in the thoracic spine TB. Paraplegia.
questions.chapter_heading: Tuberculosis Of Bone And Joints-Tb Of Bone

questions.question: Which imaging modality is considered the best for assessing vertebral body destruction and sequestrum formation in Pott’s spine?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) CT scan Explanation: A CT scan is the most preferred imaging modality for the assessment of destruction of the vertebral body and sequestrum formation. They can clearly show the extent of bony changes. X-ray: Reduction of disc space- Lateral X-ray is better for the evaluation of disc space. (Option A) In the early stages- wedging of the vertebrae. In late stages- angular kyphotic deformity . Evidence of cold abscess: Bird nest appearance of cold abscess of the thoracic region showing typical fusiform shape. Rarefaction: There is diffuse rarefaction of the vertebrae above and below the lesion. Types of lesions in the vertebral column are: Paradiscal (most common) Central Anterior Posterior ( pedicle, lamina, spinous process, and transverse process) Signs of healing: Sclerosis Sclerotic bone Bony fusion Image: AP and Lateral view of Lumbosacral spine with diminished intervertebral disc space and erosion of inferior and superior end plate of L4-L5vertebra. CT scan: (Option C) The most preferred imaging modality for the assessment of destruction of the vertebral body and sequestrum formation. The pattern of bone damage, including fragmentary, osteolytic, sclerotic, and subperiosteal changes, is clearly visible on CT scans. MRI: (Option B) Investigation of choice to evaluate the type and extent of compression of the cord. IOC for potts spine and potts paraplegia. But doesn't help to visualize bony vertebral destruction. Earlier signs, spinal nerve root, and paraspinal soft tissue are better visualized. The best diagnostic modality for spinal TB. Ultrasound (Option D): It can be used to assess soft tissue structures, fluid collections, and ultrasound-guided needle aspiration or biopsy for early histopathological diagnosis, but is not commonly utilized for evaluating bony structures or deep vertebral lesions. Therefore, it is not suitable for assessing vertebral body destruction in Pott’s spine.
questions.chapter_heading: Tuberculosis Of Bone And Joints-Tb Of Bone

questions.question: Which of the following options would be considered an indication for surgical intervention in Pott’s spine?

options.C: Worsening neural complications despite conservative treatment

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) All of the above Explanation: All of them are indications for surgical intervention in cases of Pott's spine. Management Chemotherapy (Anti-tubercular treatment) should be continued for at least 9-12 months. Providing rest to the spine during the acute phase, followed by guarded mobilization. Braces (Taylor brace) and rest during the acute phase, followed by guarded movements. Indications for surgery in patients without neurological complications Indications for surgery in patients with neurological complications Progressive bone destruction despite ATT Failure to respond to conservative therapy Paravertebral abscess when it has increased in size despite medical treatment Spinal instability caused by destruction or collapse, destruction of two or more vertebrae, kyphosis Prevention of severe kyphosis in young children with extensive dorsal lesions Large paraspinal abscess New or worsening neural complications or lack of improvement with conservative treatment Paraplegia of rapid onset or severe paraplegia Late-onset paraplegia Neural arch disease Painful paraplegia in elderly patients Spinal tumor syndrome (epidural spinal tuberculoma without osseous involvement) Surgical procedures: Costo-transversectomy Anterolateral decompression HONGKONG procedure: Anterior decompression and spinal fusion Laminectomy Middle path regimen in managing Pott’s spine: Regimen: Medical management in all patients + surgical management in the following situations: Lack of response to chemotherapy Recurrent disease Severe neurological weakness Static or progressive neuro deficit despite a course of ATT Deformity Debilitating pain Instability Reference: Apley and Solomon’s System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, Edition 10th- Page 509, 510 Garg RK, Somvanshi DS. Spinal tuberculosis: a review. The journal of spinal cord medicine. 2011 Sep 1;34(5):440-54. https:// www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK538331/#:~:text=introduced%20the%20concept%20of%20%22middle,Recurrent %20disease
questions.chapter_heading: Tuberculosis Of Bone And Joints-Tb Of Bone

questions.question: An 8-year-old girl presents with complaints of hip pain that has been progressively worsening over the last six months. She has had a noticeable loss of appetite, weight loss, and night sweats during this time. On examination, she exhibits an antalgic gait, and the X-ray image is shown below. Which stage of this condition does this patient most likely represent?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Stage IV Explanation: This case points to a diagnosis of tuberculosis of the hip (TB hip). Chronic hip pain, loss of appetite, and antalgic gait are classic indicators of a serious underlying condition like TB Site of TB infection at the hip: Acetabulum > Femur The presence of a wandering acetabulum on X-ray is consistent with Stage IV of the following classification: Babulkar and Pandey Clinico-Radiological Classification Stage Clinical Findings X-ray findings Stage I: Synovitis (Option A) Irritable hip Increased FABER (Flexion, Abduction, External Rotation) Apparent lengthening due to FABER (Position of ease due to synovitis) Terminal movements are restricted by 25% Normal or haziness of the articular margins Stage II: Early Arthritis (Option B) Early joint pain, stiffness Increased FADIR (Flexion, Adduction, Internal Rotation) Apparent shortening due to FADIR Gluteal and Quadriceps muscle wasting ROM restricted by 50% Osteopenia and narrowing of joint space Stage III: Late Arthritis (Option C) Marked FADIR True shortening Gross restriction of
questions.chapter_heading: Tuberculosis Of Bone And Joints-Tb Of Bone

questions.question: A 45-year-old male patient presents with very advanced tuberculosis of the hip. He is a manual laborer and expresses a strong desire to maintain his ability to squat, which is important for his daily activities and cultural practices. Which treatment option would be best for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Girdle Stone's Excision Explanation: Girdlestone arthroplasty allows for the removal of diseased tissue Preserve some mobility in a severely damaged hip joint. The postoperative skeletal traction aids in stabilization and promotes healing. This procedure is particularly beneficial for patients who need to maintain functional mobility, such as the ability to squat. Treatment Stage of Synovitis ATT Traction Relieves muscle spasm Gives rest to joint Prevents deformity Maintains joint space Rest and mobilization exercises (Option D) Stage of Arthritis ATT Non weight bearing ROM exercises. If unresponsive, then Synovectomy (Removal of synovium) (Option C) Joint debridement Stage of Pathological Dislocation Girdle stone's Excision Arthroplasty (Option B) Provide a painless, mobile but unstable joint Hip becomes unstable and the limb short Patient will be able to squat on the floor Preferred in countries where squatting is important(e.g. India) Total hip replacement A more costly option but provides stability and functionality. (Option A) Reference: Apley and Solomon’s System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, Edition 10th- Page 56, 57. Essential Orthopaedics Including Clinical Methods Maheshwari, Edition 6th- Pg No.198,199
questions.chapter_heading: Tuberculosis Of Bone And Joints-Tb Of Bone

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a typical feature of the triple deformity in tuberculosis of the knee?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Lateral displacement of the patella Explanation: Lateral displacement of the patella is not a typical feature of the triple deformity; the primary features involve changes in the tibia and knee flexion rather than patellar positioning. TB knee stages 1. Synovitis Boggy swelling 2. Early Arthritis Severe pain and swelling. 3. Late Arthritis/Pathological dislocation Triple deformity (Options A, C, and D) Posterior subluxation of the tibia (due to laxity of the capsule) External or lateral rotation of the tibia (due to spasm of the iliotibial band) Flexion of the knee (due to spasms of the hamstrings) Reference: Apley and Solomon’s System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, Edition 10th- Page 593,594 Essential Orthopaedics Including Clinical Methods Maheshwari, Edition 6th- Page 200-204
questions.chapter_heading: Tuberculosis Of Bone And Joints-Tb Of Bone

questions.question: A 5-year-old girl presents with a painless, progressive swelling of the middle phalanx of her left index finger for 3 months. Physical examination reveals a firm, fusiform swelling with restricted movement. X-rays show a cystic lesion in the phalanx. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Tubercular dactylitis Explanation: Tubercular dactylitis commonly presents as a painless, progressive swelling of the phalanges in young children With radiographic findings of cystic lesions and cortical thinning. The absence of pain and systemic symptoms, combined with the characteristic "spina ventosa" appearance, supports the diagnosis. TB dactylitis Also called spina ventosa- Painless spindle-shaped fingers Dactylitis is the inflammation of phalanges and metacarpals Dactylitis is primarily caused by TB Syphilis can also cause Dactylitis BCG osteomyelitis Develops when intradermal BCG vaccine hits the bone Poncet's Arthritis It is tuberculous polyarthritis resembling rheumatoid arthritis. Usually, large joints are involved in skeletal TB (Spine, hip, knee) But in this case, small joints are involved as that of rheumatoid arthritis. TB Shoulder The common variety is the dry type and is called caries sicca There is no effusion into the joint (non-exudative) Acute Osteomyelitis (Option A): Typically presents with acute pain, swelling, and systemic symptoms like fever. The swelling would be tender, hot, and associated with significant discomfort, which is not the case here. This option is incorrect. Gout (Option B): Presents with sudden, severe pain, often in the big toe. The patient's painless swelling and location (finger) are not consistent with gout. This option is incorrect. Enchondroma (Option D): This benign tumor often presents with asymptomatic lesions but typically doesn't cause spindle-shaped swelling (spina ventosa). X-ray findings would also differ (well-defined, lucent, central medullary lesions). This option is incorrect.
questions.chapter_heading: Tuberculosis Of Bone And Joints-Tb Of Bone

questions.question: A known healed case of TB spine presents with lower limb neurological symptoms with bowel and bladder involvement. What can be the most likely cause?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Angular kyphosis Explanation: Pott's disease with neurological manifestation is called Pott’s paraplegia. In a healed TB case, kyphosis is a common long-term complication due to the destruction of vertebral bodies leading to compression of the spinal cord or nerve roots in the thoracic or lumbar region, causing neurological symptoms in the lower limbs and bowel and bladder. Pott’s paraplegia: (TB Spine with Neurological Involvement) Early-onset paraplegia Etiology Inflammatory causes Abscess – commonest (Option B) Granulation tissue (Option A) Circumscribed tuberculous focus Posterior spinal disease Infective thrombosis of the spinal blood supply (Option D) Mechanical causes Sequestrum in the canal Infected degenerated disc in the canal Pathological dislocation - a ridge of bone pressing on the cord Late-onset paraplegia Etiology Causes Recurrence of the disease Prominent anterior wall of the spinal canal in case of severe kyphosis (Internal gibbus) Angular kyphosis Fibrous septae following healing Clinical manifestations: Back Pain Paraparesis (partial paralysis) and then complete paraplegia due to spinal cord compression Sensory loss below the level of spinal involvement Bladder and bowel dysfunction, especially in later stages Kyphosis Gibbus deformity is common due to vertebral collapse Angular kyphosis Neurological symptoms can be acute, subacute, or chronic Subacute or chronic forms are more typical, with gradual worsening over weeks to months Vertebral collapse or abscess can cause acute neurological symptoms. The thoracic spine is the most commonly involved Investigations: MRI- investigation of choice CT- to better visualize the vertebral canal Treatment: Conservative therapy: ATT is the mainstay of treatment. Absolute rest - sling traction for the cervical spine, and bed rest for the dorso lumbar spine. Followed by guarded mobilization. Surgical therapy: Indication: No improvement in paraplegia Worsening of symptoms Reference: Apley and Solomon’s System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, Edition 10th- Page 508, 509, 510 Essential Orthopaedics Including Clinical Methods Maheshwari, Edition 6th- Page 191-94
questions.chapter_heading: Tuberculosis Of Bone And Joints-Tb Of Bone
